Authors:
Darryl Arthur Herron, Michael J Wingfield, Brenda D
Wingfield, Carlos A. Rodas, Seonju Marincowitz, Emma T Steenkamp
Title:
Novel Fusarium species in the Gibberella fujikuroi species
complex from Pinus spp. in Colombia
Keywords:
F. fracticaudum, F. marasasianum, Fusarium parvisorum, F.
pinemorale, F. sororula, morphology, pathogenicity, phylogenetics, Pinus
kesiya, P. maximinoi, P. patula, P. tecunumanii
Abstract:
The pitch canker pathogen Fusarium circinatum has caused
devastation to Pinus spp. in natural forests and in plantions of Pinus
spp. growing as non-natives in commercially managed plantatons. This has
drawn attention to the potential importance of Fusarium species as
pathogens of forest trees. In this study, we explored the diversity of
Fusarium species associated with diseased Pinus patula, P. tecunumanii,
P. kesiya and P. maximinoi in Colombian plantations and nurseries.
Plants displaying symptoms typical of F. circinatum infection (i.e. stem
cankers and branch die-back on trees in plantations and root or collar
rot of seedlings) were sampled. A total of 57 isolates were collected
and characterized based on DNA sequence data for the TEF and β-tubulin
gene regions. Phylogenetic analyses of these data allowed for the
identification of 10 Fusarium species. These included F. circinatum, F.
oxysporum, F. solani and seven novel species in the Gibberella fujikuroi
complex, five of which are described here as Fusarium parvisorum sp.
nov., F. fracticaudum sp. nov., Fusarium marasasianum sp. nov., F.
pinemorale sp. nov. and F. sororula sp. nov. Selected isolates of the
five new species were tested for their pathogencity on Pinus patula and
compared with that of F. circinatum. Of these, F. pinemorale sp. nov.
and F. parvisorum sp. nov. displayed levels of pathogenicity to P.
patula, that were comparable with that of F. circinatum. These
apparently emerging pathogens thus pose a significant risk to forestry
in Colombia and other parts of the world.
